text: My son started a new job as a data engineer.
The other day he called me in the middle of the afternoon,
a little panicked, and he never really calls.
His downstream users were not very happy.
The problem is they weren't getting the data they needed for sensitive reports.
But little did they know that the issue was not with his team,
but it was coming from the upstream system.
Does this sound familiar to you?
I have heard similar stories many, many times.
One way to solve this issue is to use data contracts.
So what is the data contract?
It's an agreement between a data producer and one or many data consumers.
And they share a data contract.
So the data contract, why we do we do that?
It's because we want better documentation, we want better data quality, and we want better SLAs.
And what is the ultimate goal of that?
It's to really lower the cost of AI.
You don't have to retrain your models.
You get better data in your system so you don't have the garbage in, garbage out.
To do that, we follow a standard called the "Open Data Contract Standard",
and it is a standard backed by the Linux Foundation.
It is composed of eight sections.
Demographics, which is really your name, version, detailed information about your data contract.
Then you've got your data set and schema representing what the data is about,
associated to your data quality rules.
You've got the pricing section, which currently is experimental,
but if you want to share your data within your organization or outside your organization,
you can specify rules.
You've got stakeholders
where you see how the contract was being evolved by the different people
involved in the creation and maintenance of the contract.
You've got rules for security access,
service level agreements
and custom property for future reference and extensions.
So coming back to my son, how this would have helped this problem:
by having better data quality rules and better SLAs,
it would have prevented the issues and given these customers the data they expected.
And I hope for the next time he calls me, it's just to say, "Hello, Papa".
Thanks for watching.
Before you leave, please remember to hit like and subscribe.
